title: LR circuits - steady state current for L and 2 Rs

content.description: An inductor with inductance <math alttext="4.0 milli Henries" overflow="scroll"><mn>4.0</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>mH</mtext></math>, a resistor with resistance <math alttext="6.0 kilo ohms" overflow="scroll"><mn>6.0</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>kΩ</mtext></math>, and a resistor with resistance <math alttext="12 kilo ohms" overflow="scroll"> <mn>12</mn> <mspace width="0.2em"> </mspace> <mtext>kΩ</mtext> </math> are connected to a battery with <math alttext="e m f" overflow="scroll"><mtext>emf</mtext></math> <math alttext="6.0 volts" overflow="scroll"><mn>6.0</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>V</mtext></math> and an initially open switch, as shown. The switch is then closed.
content.question: What is the current in the battery a long time after the switch has been closed?

topic.text: 13.5: Circuits with Resistors and Inductors (LR Circuits)

skill.text: 2.B: Calculate or estimate an unknown quantity with units from known quantities, by selecting and following a logical computational pathway.
